Page.Title: Where does the concept of responsible officer fit into APRA licensing system?

PageElement.TextBox:
The licensing regime administered by the Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority (APRA) requires licensed superannuation trustees that are companies to have responsible officers.  These officers are directors and executives of the companies that are the trustees that administer the super funds.
 
The APRA responsible officers can be contrasted with both the concept of "officer" under the Corporations Act 2001, as well as the "responsible manager" concept applied by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) for their financial services licensees. 
 
It is important that everyone understands the ROs' legal duties and responsibilities - the superannuation trustee companies and the ROs themselves. This is part of APRA's licensing requirements.

PageElement.TextBox:
What is unique about superannuation law? 
 
Superannuation law is unusual because it is made up of a mixture of: 
 
  • Corporations laws (Corporations Act 2001)
  • General law (such as contract, tort, case law)
  • Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (SIS Act)
  • Trust law 
 
These four major areas make up the complex legal back drop of making a superannuation fund compliant with the laws of Australia.  All sources of law are important. Regulators tend to enforce both the SIS Act and Corporations Act.  Members of super funds may bring actions using the general law and trust law, as well as parts of the legislation.

PageElement.TextBox:
Which regulators are involved? 
 
Superannuation funds have three major Commonwealth regulators.  Each regulator has a different focus and a different operational approach to regulating super.  The three regulators are: 
 
  • the Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority (APRA), which has a prudential supervisory role. A licensing scheme was introduced for super funds in 2006
 
  • the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC), which has a consumer protection focus and overall responsibility for licensing through the Australian Financial Services Licences (AFSL) regime
 
  • the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), which regulates the taxation of super and other related issues, and has a role as supervisory regulator of self-managed superannuation funds (or SMSFs).

• Click here to read a real example
    Trio Capital Limited
     
    In March 2012 John Godfrey, a former Trio Capital Limited (Trio) director, became the sixth former Trio director to make an enforceable undertaking accepted by APRA. Godfrey is the first former Trio director who left the board prior to its 2009 collapse to give an enforceable undertaking.
     
    Godfrey was a non-executive director of Trio from February 2005 until June 2007 and was the Chairman from June 2005 to February 2007. APRA was concerned that Trio had failed to redeem existing investments. Trio had also made ongoing investments in EFL, an offshore hedge fund, in circumstances of concern to APRA. Trio also failed to redeem existing investments and made ongoing investments in ASF in similar circumstances of concern.
     
    Under this enforceable undertaking, Godfrey has undertaken, without APRA's prior written consent, not to act as a responsible officer or trustee of an APRA-regulated superannuation entity.
     
    APRA also accepted enforceable undertakings from other former Trio directors: David O'Bryen, Keith Finkelde David Andrews, Rex Phillpott and Natasha Beck.
     
    Under these undertakings the former directors have undertaken not to act as a responsible officer or trustee of an APRA regulated superannuation entity.

PageElement.TextBox:
What is all the fuss about responsible officers? 
 
The Corporate Law Economic Reform Program (known as "CLERP") between 2002 and 2004 revolutionised the way financial services in Australia operated -- in particular, the licensing regime.   
 
Prior to the Financial Services Reform Act 2001 (which was based on "CLERP 6"), there were different types of licences, depending on which financial services were being provided.  With the introduction of the Financial Services Reform Act, this was simplified to a single licence only, called an "Australian Financial Services Licence" (often referred to as an "AFSL").  All public offer super funds were required to obtain an AFSL from ASIC in respect of the financial services that they provided. 
 
The introduction of the "superannuation safety" legislation and the additional regulation by APRA of Registrable Superannuation Entities (RSEs) under the SIS Act in 2006, provided an additional level of security for the industry but also resulted in additional compliance costs.  However, APRA has stated that it has carefully learnt from the issues that arose from ASIC's AFSL licensing program and has tried to make the process as effective and efficient as possible.
 
Click here to access a link to the SIS Act

The main purpose of the RO in the context of the APRA licensing regime is to enable the RSE to demonstrate that its senior people satisfy the "Fit and Proper" test under the SIS Act.  
 
APRA's ultimate goal in administering the RSE licensing regime is to promote high standards of compliance, risk management and governance within the superannuation industry.

Page.Title: Differences between ROs, RMs and officers

PageElement.TextBox:
What are the differences between an APRA "RO", an ASIC "RM" and a corporate "officer"?
 
There can be much confusion between the definition of a nominated Responsible Manager under the ASIC licensing regime and the Responsible Officer under the APRA licensing regime. The main differences include:  
 
ASIC RMs
  • are part of the AFS licensing process administered by ASIC
  • are a category of person nominated by an AFS licensee by which the AFS licensee may demonstrate to ASIC that it is able to discharge its statutory duty to maintain the competence to provide the financial services it is licensed to provide
  • do not have any personal obligations under the Corporations Act 2001; this is not a statutory office attracting its own obligations and liabilities under the Corporations Act, as is the case with directors or other officers under the Corporations Act
 
APRA ROs
  • are part of the Registrable Superannuation Entity (RSE) licensing process administered by APRA
  • are defined in s 10 of the SIS Act
  • all staff who fulfil the definition, such as directors, secretaries or executives, will be deemed ROs 
  • have certain technical functions under the SIS Act, but the main requirement under the SIS Act is that they must be "fit and proper" persons
  • ASIC or the Federal Court of Australia may disqualify a person from being an RO if they have contravened certain laws
 
Officers
  • are defined in s 9 of the Corporations Act to include a director, secretary or senior manager
  • are subject to strict legal duties under the law
  • there is a lot of case law which helps explain the meaning of "officer" of a corporation

What are the APRA licences and the need for a registered fund? 
 
APRA's RSE licence regulates which individuals and which corporate entities may act as suppliers of superannuation products and services within the superannuation industry.  
 
The SIS Act requires superannuation trustees to hold an RSE licence issued by APRA.  Once the trustee has been licensed as an RSE, they are then able to register various super funds under the single RSE licence with APRA.

Page.Title: What does APRA require before an RSE licence is granted?

PageElement.TextBox:
APRA has a variety of licensing requirements that must be satisfied before a RSE licence is granted and in order to maintain the licence once granted. The applicant for an RSE licence must satisfy the following: 
 
  • Meet the "Fit and Proper" standard
  • Disclose material outsourcing of agreements
  • Demonstrate that it will comply with relevant laws and the conditions on the licence
  • Have adequate human, technological and financial resources
  • Have a risk management strategy
  • Have a risk management plan 
 
Of these the most important requirement for ROs is the requirement for the licensee to satisfy the "Fit and Proper standard" test. This fitness and propriety standard strictly applies to the RSE licensee. However, both the RSE licensee and each of its responsible officers are required to be "fit and proper". This requirement applies not just at the stage of applying for an RSE licence, but also during the course of holding the RSE licence.

Page.Title: Satisfying the Fit and Proper test

PageElement.TextBox:
How does a licensee satisfy the "Fit and Proper" test? 
 
The "Fit and Proper standard" is outlined in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and Regulations.  The operating standards prescribe that: 
 
"…an RSE licensee meets the fit and proper standard if the RSE licensee possess relevant attributes that enable the RSE licensee to properly discharge the duties and responsibilities of an RSE licensee in a prudent manner". 
 
"Relevant attributes" include that a corporate licensee must hold particular educational qualifications, technical qualifications and must possess knowledge and skills relevant to the duties and responsibilities of an RSE licensee.  
 
Both the "fitness" and the "propriety" limbs of the Fit and Proper standard apply both to the trustee and to its responsible officers.
 
APRA's Prudential Practice Guide states that APRA expects that all ROs will possess appropriate skills,
knowledge and qualifications to carry out their appointed roles in order to meet the fitness limb of the standard. In APRA’s view, minimum requirements for all responsible officers of a trustee would include:
 
  • an understanding of and an ability to implement the principles of section 52 of the SIS Act
  • knowledge of the SIS Act and the SIS Regulations  and other prudential requirements
  • a working knowledge of the accounting, auditing and operational processes relating to the trustee and those funds it manages
  • basic investment knowledge
  • basic knowledge of RSE licensee law 
  • awareness of areas where additional technical, professional or expert advice could be sought
 
The Prudential Practice Guide states that, in respect of "fitness", APRA does not intend to set specific educational or technical qualifications, levels of knowledge, skills and experience to be demonstrated by licence applicants or trustees or their responsible officers. That is, each RO does not have to be a "superannuation expert". However, licensees should conduct induction and training for its ROs and should review the fitness and propriety of its ROs at least annually.

Page.Title: Requirements of the Fit and Proper test

PageElement.TextBox:
Further requirements on the Fit and Proper Test:  
 
If an entity seeking an RSE licence does not possess a particular skill, the skill can be sourced from an outside party.   Investment expertise or specific skills and knowledge can be gained through other third parties. Entities seeking RSE licences may hire an employee with these skills or engage the services of a consultant who will provide these services or skills.  
 
 
APRA will examine the "propriety" of each individual. This test involves examining the individual's:  
 
  • character
  • competence
  • diligence
  • experience
  • honesty
  • integrity
  • judgement
 
The propriety limb of the standard must be met at all times by the trustee and by the RO, not just at the time of applying for an RSE licence.

So how does APRA determine who is "Fit and Proper"? 
 
All RSE licence applications must include for their ROs: 
 
  • an up to date curriculum vitae
  • an Australian Federal Police check for criminal convictions
  • "a detailed explanation and supporting evidence as to how the applicant (RSE licensee) meets the requirements of the Fit and Proper Operating Standard"
  • details of any Executive or Non-Executive Director positions held with another corporation that is not the trustee corporation applying for the licence
  • details of any major shareholdings that exceed 10 per cent of the total amount of shares on issue
  • if he/she derives any financial benefit, either directly or indirectly from an entity that provides services to the trustee, the name of the entity
 
In its assessment as to whether a trustee or RSE licence applicant meets the requirements of the standard, APRA will examine the policy and processes that the trustee has developed to ensure that the fit and proper requirements are satisfied on an ongoing basis, and are regularly reviewed by the trustee.
 
These policies will periodically examine the trustees' fitness and propriety requirements.  They will cover: 
 
  • the compliance procedures to confirm a candidate's claims
  • procedures to ensure that the responsible officers are not disqualified
  • procedures to ensure that adequate and ongoing training is supplied
  • the correct induction procedures to be followed
  • removal systems to ensure that persons found not to be "fit and proper" will be removed from their position

What are the general duties and responsibilities of officers of corporations? 
 
In addition to APRA RO responsibilities and ASIC RM requirements, directors and other corporate officers have a range of duties and responsibilities.  These include:  
 
(1) duties imposed by the courts through their judgments in cases 
 
(2) duties imposed by Parliament 
 
    • These include duties imposed under the Corporations Act 2001.
    • These can change continuously as legislation is amended  (eg CLERP). 
 
(3) ASIC and APRA prudential standards, regulatory guides and guidance notes

Ongoing compliance procedures to enable continued satisfaction of Fit and Proper standard include such things as ongoing monitoring and review, and seeking up-to-date statements of personal information.

Which Corporations Act provisions must officers comply with? 
 
  • Duty to take reasonable care and diligence: s180
  • Duty to act in good faith in the best interests of the corporation and for a proper purpose: s181
  • Duty not to misuse position: s 182
  • Duty not to misuse information: s 183.
 
There are range of civil and criminal provisions in the Corporations Act for a breach of these duties.
 
In summary, an officer must take reasonable care and diligence, act in good faith and for a proper purpose, must not misuse position to their own advantage, and must not misuse information. 
 
In relation to the standard of care, a director or other officer must exercise duties with the same degree of care and diligence as a reasonable person would if they: 
 
  • were a director or other officer of that corporation in its circumstances
  • occupied that office and had the same responsibilities within the corporation as the direct or other officer. 
 
An officer satisfies this duty of care and diligence if he or she:
 
  • made their judgment in good faith and for a proper purpose
  • does not have a material interest in the subject matter
  • informs themselves about the subject matter to the extent they reasonably believe to be appropriate, and
  • rationally believes the judgment is in the best interests of the corporation.

Page.Title: What protection is available to an RO?

PageElement.TextBox:
Under the SIS Act, a trustee is indemnified from the assets of a superannuation fund for liability incurred while acting as the trustee (under section 56), and s 57 provides the same security for trustees' directors.  Further, directors and other officers are usually indemnified from the company of which they are a director/officer, and the company usually takes out directors' and officers' insurance in respect of its directors and other officers.
 
However, the Corporations Act limits this indemnity: 
 
  • trustee directors will remain personally liable where the corporate trustee is not entitled to be fully indemnified against the liability out of trust assets because the trustee breached its duties s 197
  • there are restrictions on the ability of a company indemnifying its officers against liabilities owed by the officer, including legal costs in defending an action for a liability incurred as an officer s 199A
  • a corporate trustee must not pay an insurance premium for a contract of insurance that insures an officer against liability arising out of a wilful breach of the officer's duties s 199B
 
Two High Court decisions in Australia affected the degree to which directors can escape liability or receive indemnity from the corporation.

PageElement.TextBox: It is important however, to remember that no insurance can ever cover criminal liability, such as fraud, but defence costs may be advanced. This will depend upon the terms of your policy and may need careful checking in the light of the requirements of the Corporations Act 2001 and the decisions of the courts.
